title: Argos shouldn't break the bank for QB Trevor Harris
text:
Argos QB Trevor Harris could be next face of franchise TORONTO - 
With the season drawing closer to an end, the rumours and speculation and behind-the-scenes posturing involving teams and player agents kicks into high gear. 
The situation with the Argos is unlike any in the CFL given the team’s incoming ownership group and the potential to actually make money with BMO Field looming on the horizon. 
No one knows with any certainty what kind of attraction an intimate stadium with suitable dates will have on the turnstile, but any setup that does not involve Rogers Centre must be viewed as favourable. 
Had MLSE stepped forward to assume ownership of the Argos, the possibilities seemed endless, the big-time money-making outfit expanding to include three-down football as part of its sporting stable along with the Leafs, Raptors and TFC, making the move to BMO that much more amenable. 
The thought of luring a free agent to Toronto seemed too tempting, a player being courted at an NBA game sitting courtside, a free agent brought to town watching an NHL game from the luxury of a suite. 
It would have been the envy of the league. 
Any arrangement that doesn’t involve David Braley must also be viewed as favourable, though no one should ever dismiss the efforts he has made and the money he has poured into the franchise. 
Braley deserves credit, but he also needs to be held accountable for his abandonment and indifference. 
Argos general manager Jim Barker and head coach Scott Milanovich have had their hands tied, but the incoming ownership of Bell and Larry Tanenbaum’s Kilmer Group did the right thing in inking both Barker and Milanovich to three-year deals. 
While their hands remain tied, discussions have begun. 
At the centre of these talks is Trevor Harris, an intriguing quarterback who could very well be the beneficiary of Milanovich’s offence, the same offence that allowed Zach Collaros to shine before Collaros signed a free-agent deal with Hamilton. 
Until he suffered a season-ending knee injury in a game against Edmonton, the Ticats were well on their way to their third successive Grey Cup appearance with Collaros head and shoulders the leading candidate to cop the CFL’s MOP. 
Collaros will soon undergo surgery and the Argos will soon have to decide the fate of Harris and by extension the future of Ricky Ray. 
One will have to go, one will be retained. 
Whomever is allowed to leave will likely end up in Montreal, where the Als have yet to find a suitable replacement for Anthony Calvillo. 
There has always been talk that one of Ray or Harris will land in Ottawa given the connection with Jason Maas, but the way Henry Burris has been slinging the pigskin the 40-year-old has shown he still has game. 
No free agent will be extended in Argoland until the new owners officially take over, likely in early December. 
While nothing can get done, there has been talk. And the talk is that representatives for Harris are asking their client be the highest-paid quarterback in the CFL. 
It’s a shocker, but perhaps not surprising given how Harris has performed in Ray’s absence. 
The number being floated around is $450,000, Ray money, only Harris isn’t Ray. 
Both players are good people, good teammates and among the classiest in the CFL. 
Harris could very well dictate terms if he’s able to produce in the post-season and even win a Grey Cup. But as of now, there’s no way the Argos should even consider such a salary for Harris. 
Maybe there is a team out there willing to fork over the kind of money that’s being talked about, perhaps Harris may actually stay in Toronto if the team continues to win. 
The Argos tried to work out a deal to keep Collaros, but he wanted to be the man and that’s when the Ticats pounced. 
Collaros benefitted from playing in the Milanovich system, but what separates Collaros from the rest is his ability to make plays with his feet, a gunslinger mentality that is second to none. 
The Argos brought both Collaros and Harris to town in 2012. During training camp last season, the Argos gave Harris an extension. 
The CFL, with so many injuries to front-line quarterbacks, has been on a youth kick, fresh-faced quarterbacks performing to mixed reviews. 
Harris has shown he’s a starter, but he has yet to play in a playoff game. 
Ray has won three Grey Cups and it’s why he deserves to be paid handsomely. 
Despite the growth Harris has shown in helping lead the Argos to a 9-5 season, the jury is still out. 
The Argos don’t know what Ray has left, but he is getting closer to playing. 
It’s always been a quarterback conundrum that faced the Argos, a team moving forward with no signal caller under contract beyond this season. 
Barker, Milanovich and Ray were always tied together. 
When Barker and Milanovich were extended, Ray was excluded. 
It made sense given Ray was coming off a shoulder procedure in the off-season. 
What doesn’t make sense is to make Harris the highest-paid quarterback. 
ARGOS WILL CALL THE HAMMER HOME 
The Argos’ home/road show will now officially involve the Hammer. 
The team released a statement on Tuesday, confirming that this Saturday’s game against Calgary will be played at Tim Hortons Field in Hamilton. 
Kickoff is 4 p.m. and no one is willing to estimate what kind of crowd, what kind of environment, what kind of reception awaits. 
What’s known is that the Argos have rallied around the many issues that don’t involve football, winning home games played in Fort McMurray and Ottawa. 
The sad part is that the Argos should have been home for the season’s final four games with a legitimate shot of winning the East and playing host to the divisional final with a berth in the Grey Cup on the line. 
They may yet come out on top, but playing a home game in Hamilton isn’t what anyone associated with football operations could have envisioned. 
If the Jays advance and keep advancing, more home games in Hamilton will be played, the next involving the Oct. 23 matchup with Montreal. 
In three visits to Tim Hortons Field, the Argos have lost each game to the host Ticats. 
The Stamps beat Hamilton on its home turf in Calgary’s first visit.
